There's something very comforting about the bottom right corner of the box labeling the game as "park simulation".

Konami released a trio of JP3 games at the same time on the GBA and they all have this genre identifier in the corner to set them apart lol

I was assigned to review all three for a small website a long time ago. The park builder was the best of the three. The other two are not worth even remembering their names.

Rebelstar: Galactic Command, which has the most wild game cover ever:

The actual game looks like

Also it's a tactical game by fuckin julian gollop

I have to check this out! o.o

Came here for hidden gems, then got recommendation like Golden Sun, Megaman, Final Fantasy?? Common people you can do better.

My recommendation is Sigma Star Saga.

It's an ARPG + Shmups. Both rpg part and Shmups parts are really fun and they're interconnected. You can get experience in Shmups sections and you can also get parts to upgrade your ship from RPG section. Graphics and story is good too.

And you sold me on that game, I'll put it on the list! :D

I replayed them all last year and I still love them all, some more some less but I think they are all still great. It was a bit easy to get lost in MMBN2 and 3 but MMBN4-6 streamlined the internet. I can see however how people might not like the fifth entry, the story and the SRPG battles are really a bit meh. Okay and I skipped the first game because that aged far more roughly than the rest though with the DS remaster having a English patch now I might have to grab a copy if it's cheap and play that instead.

One thing I noticed, the themes and events seem a bit more disturbing to adult-me than than they felt as a kid, realizing what the WWW really does and the end of MMBN2 in the final parts where the real and the digital worlds merge.

I plan to tackle Starforce this year! :D

I agree, but even then the combat is sadly a bit too sparse in all aspects, like a SRPG lite. Still the moment where Pharsti goes Orbital Frame is amazing and gives me chills to this day! :D

I've been meaning to play them eventually actually, are they cheap to import?

Star force is good too if you haven't played it. I recently replayed 1. It definitely ages the worst but I still have fun playing it.

Zone of the Enders: The Fist of Mars is a terrible game but about the best Visual Novel to be found on the GBA I think.

I had this game and could never get into it when I was a teen (I ended up skipping the story, should've given it a go). The action-time aiming system was terrible though.

Other than that I recommend Summon Night: Swordcraft Story 1 & 2. They're both great games; good combat, characters, music, mostly light hearted fun. The first one is more focused on a gameplay loop between going through a massive labyrinth and upgrading things in your town, while the second is a much larger in scale RPG. It has Tales' style combat and fun crafting system.

Damn, I remember wanting to play this game so much after seeing screenshots in magazines.

Konami Krazy Racers is a better kart racer than Mario Kart Super Circuit in pretty much every regard, it is wacky, fast, has a really fun roster (Vic Viper! Bear Tank! Dracula! Goemon!) and top notch music.

Boktai: The Sun is in Your Hand.

It's an action game produced by Hideo Kojima where you play as a vampire hunter named Django who's... well, hunting vampires. It's played from an isometric perspective, and has some light stealth mechanics in the vein of Metal Gear (you can get against a wall and tap on it to attract enemies to that spot, etc.).

The cool part is that your weapon, the Gun del Sol, kills things with sunlight... literally. The game cart has a built-in solar sensor that detects sunlight, and you use that to replenish your gun's energy/ammunition. If you run out of energy and it isn't sunny out (or you don't have a blacklight nearby), you have to try to sneak your way past enemies (or just generally avoid them). The sensor also detects the intensity of the sunlight, so if it's a really sunny day, your energy recharges more quickly (and iirc, it will also restore your health). It's a really cool system.

The game's kind of expensive nowadays unfortunately, but it's a really unique game that I think is worth playing. The sequels are good too (though the third game never released outside of Japan, and the fourth game on DS is very different and not as good as the rest).

Also: if you get your hands on a cart and don't want to mess with the solar sensor (or if the sensor is broken or something), you can rip the ROM and apply a fanmade patch that lets you manually adjust the sunlight levels using the GBA's shoulder buttons. It takes some of the fun out of it, but it's still a solid game regardless.

Some more screenshots! Unfortunately most of the screenshots online are from the first areas but the game has your classic zelda spread of environments, with snow, swamp and desert biomes.

Oh, and it has a whole Pokemon style monster collecting side-quest.

Well, this is what I played last night :

- DemiKids : Dark

A SMT spin-off which aimed at surfing on the Pok√©mon trend. Didn't really like it. My not-Persona favourite spin-off stays Another Bible on Game Boy (the T-RPG) but the quest continues

- Astro Boy

I actually had played this one already but I... had forgotten about. What a blast! Definitely revisiting it later. I'm stuck at the beginning of world 2 yet but it shouldn't last too long.

- Starfy

I had played it already a couple of years ago but very very briefly. I really love it. What a gem.

- Star Wars Episode III

I did NOT expect that, but then again I wasn't THAT surprised. Super Return of the Jedi (Game Boy, not SNES) was one of my favourite games as a kid. I'm a sucker for Star Wars beat'em all and platformers so that was fun.

Noted a lot of really really intriguing games that I'm going to try tonight. Thanks for your inputs :D Man, the GBA has a great library. I kind of feel bad for overlooking it.

I would recommend you buy this game. It pushes the Game Boy Advance hardware with the amount of enemies that can appear on-screen. Zero slow-down. As you can see from the cover art it has dinosaurs. Another thing it has is a time-slowing mechanic (fyi, it is also made by the same developer who made Max Payne on GBA). And there is 4 player death match available via one cartridge! Check it out.

I would recommend checking this out if you're a fan of the Rolling Thunder series. I enjoyed this quite a lot more than Metal Slug Advance. The boss fights are always a pleasure. The last level is highly memorable and well executed.
